results.title: Elements of surface hardening
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, United States. Office of Education and Audio Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Engineering heat treatment of steel”.
Shows how steel is pack and gas carburised; how a thin, hard case is obtained by cyaniding; how nitriding is used to obtain a very hard case; and how steel is flame and induction hardened.

results.title: Peter & Paul and the Christian revolution
results.creator_credit: Margaret Koval, Patricia Aste and Koval Films LLC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Traces the life of early Christians Peter and Paul, who faced powerful obstacles - including the mighty Roman Empire, political persecution and crippling personal disagreements - in their attempts to spread the word of Jesus. Episode 1. “The Rock and the river” - With the Messiah dead and their cause deemed subversive, the followers of Jesus face a bleak future, until their hope is re-invigorated by a vision of the risen Jesus. A former persecutor of Christians, Peter soon becomes an indomitable figure, uniting the group into a tight community of ardent believers. Paul, educated, passionate, determined and dogmatic, uses his formidable talents to spread his new beliefs around the Roman Empire. Episode 2. “The Empire and the Kingdom” - Led by missionaries, Christian ideas continue to spread among Jews and non-Jews throughout the Empire; hostile locals, imperial forces and conflicting ideas threaten the future of the movement. Paul splits with his former allies, establishing churches in his image; in 70 AD, after decades of tensions, a four-year war erupts that destroys much of Jerusalem, but the communities established by Paul survive and grow. Fascinating work features the words of Paul and other ancient writers, historical re-enactments and interviews with contemporary scholars.

results.title: Kingdom of David: the saga of the Israelites [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mitch Wilson, Carl Byker and Oregon Public Broadcasting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Kingdom of David: the saga of the Israelites is the story of one of the most profoundly influential religions, Judaism. This illuminating work features historical re-enactments, as well as interviews with contemporary scholars, to recall the ancient worlds depicted in the Bible. Episode 1. “By the rivers of Babylon”: In 586 BC, the Israelites were exiled in Babylon and seemed destined to disappear; but they fought back by writing a book using Judean stories to explain the present disastrous situations - the Bible. Episode 2. “The Book and the sword”: In 458 BC a scribe named Ezra arrived in Jerusalem from Babylon; gathering the mostly illiterate Judeans together he read the Bible to them. In the following years study of the Bible became an essential part of Jewish life. Episode 3. “The End of days”: When the Roman General Pompeii led his legions into the land of Judea in 63 BC it was the beginning of a clash of cultures that grew into one of the most brutal conflicts in history. Terrorism, political assassination, starvation and crucifixion dominated the landscape, ending with the Roman sack of Jerusalem and the destruction of the Temple in 70 AD. From the aftermath, two new religions rose: rabbinical Judaism and Christianity. Episode 4. “The Gifts of the Jews”: In 132 AD Jewish zealots rebelled against Rome’s legions, forcing them to withdraw from the region. The Romans returned with a vast army, slaughtered nearly 600,000 Jews, changed the name of the region from Judea to Palestine and banned all Jews from Jerusalem. Many Jews fled to distant lands only to face another challenge - a breakaway form of Judaism called Christianity.

results.title: Queen Victoria's empire
results.creator_credit: Paul Burgess, Paul Bryers, Brook Lapping, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
At the time of Queen Victoria’s birth in 1819 England was an agrarian society; within a few short decades this nation would be transformed into an industrial superpower, with an empire spanning the globes. This captivating four part series covers the transition with historical re-enactments, stills and interviews with historians, providing a portrait of Queen Victoria and British imperialism. Episode 1. “Engines of change”: Explores the changes brought to Britain by the industrial revolution, urban migration, overcrowding, extremes in poverty and pollution of the 1840s and Prince Albert’s role. Episode 2. “Passage to India”: In the 1850s, as steamships take British goods around the globe, tensions rise in India with a clash of Victorian values and Indian culture, resulting in the Great Mutiny and Cawnpore massacre of 1857; also covers the Crimean War and the death of Prince Albert. Episode 3. “The Moral Crusade”: By 1861 Britain is the wealthiest and most powerful nation on earth; David Livingstone’s explorations of the African interior fascinate the British public; Disraeli and Gladstone battle for control of the government; colonisation of Africa begins. Episode 4. “The scramble for Africa”: The Suez Canal is threatened by a holy war in the Sudan; Cecil Rhodes prospects diamond deposits in South Africa and asserts regional control; the Boer War leads to devastating British losses; Queen Victoria’s death marks the end of an era.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Burgess, Paul Bryers, Brook Lapping, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)

results.title: The Energy audit
results.creator_credit: Mark Poole, John Hipwell, Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria and Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Energy management in commercial buildings”.
Designed as part of a series of videos outlining practical ways to measure energy use in commercial buildings, this video concentrates on conducting an energy audit. In turn, this will help the building manager in completing an energy management program with the aim of identifying opportunities for energy cost saving.

results.title: Martin Luther
results.creator_credit: Cassian Harrison, Richard Bradley, Lion Television, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Born in Germany at the height of the Black Death, Martin Luther was raised in a Europe dominated spiritually, economically and politically by the Roman Catholic Church. This two part series, narrated by Liam Neeson, explores the life of this important revolutionary thinker. In episode one, “Driven To Defiance”, we are taken through Luther’s early childhood and years as a student where his deepening spiritual faith leads him to a vocation as a monk. But on making a pilgrimage to the Vatican in Rome, he discovers a corrupt and bloated Church and a degenerate and cynical priesthood. The experience leads him to the writing of the 95 Theses, a call to arms against religious corruption and a return to the gospels of Jesus Christ. Central to the theses is Luther’s attack on the Catholic Church’s selling of Indulgence which are meant to ensure a dying person’s passage to Heaven. In calling for a spiritual renewal of Christianity, Luther’s 95 Theses lay the foundations for Protestantism. In episode two, “The Reluctant Revolutionary”, the Catholic Church responds to Luther’s attacks by charging him with heresy. But a fortunate historic confluence - the invention of the printing press - allows for the first time the wide dissemination of Luther’s ideas and beliefs which find popular support all across Europe. Luther attacks the Church hierarchy at his trial and his protests leads to revolutionary upheaval across the continent. The episode examines both Luther’s radical impact but also his refusal to support the peasant revolutionaries inspired by his rhetoric. Luther can imagine a spiritual revolutionary order but not an economic revolution. His vehement and ruthless attacks against the poor, the peasantry and against the Jews will resonate in Protestantism through the ages and lead to a tension in the Christian faiths which will see Catholicism brave the Reformation and paradoxically regain strength in the modern world as the Christian Church for the poor and the oppressed. Whatever the contradictions of his faith and life, the religious revolution inspired by Luther is undoubtedly one of the greatest singular moments in European history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cassian Harrison, Richard Bradley, Lion Television, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)

In calling for a spiritual renewal of Christianity, Luther’s 95 Theses lay the foundations for Protestantism. In episode two, “The Reluctant Revolutionary”, the Catholic Church responds to Luther’s attacks by charging him with heresy. But a fortunate historic confluence - the invention of the printing press - allows for the first time the wide dissemination of Luther’s ideas and beliefs which find popular support all across Europe. Luther attacks the Church hierarchy at his trial and his protests leads to revolutionary upheaval across the continent. The episode examines both Luther’s radical impact but also his refusal to support the peasant revolutionaries inspired by his rhetoric. Luther can imagine a spiritual revolutionary order but not an economic revolution. His vehement and ruthless attacks against the poor, the peasantry and against the Jews will resonate in Protestantism through the ages and lead to a tension in the Christian faiths which will see Catholicism brave the Reformation and paradoxically regain strength in the modern world as the Christian Church for the poor and the oppressed. Whatever the contradictions of his faith and life, the religious revolution inspired by Luther is undoubtedly one of the greatest singular moments in European history.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Born in Germany at the height of the Black Death, Martin Luther was raised in a Europe dominated spiritually, economically and politically by the Roman Catholic Church. This two part series, narrated by Liam Neeson, explores the life of this important revolutionary thinker. In episode one, “Driven To Defiance”, we are taken through Luther’s early childhood and years as a student where his deepening spiritual faith leads him to a vocation as a monk. But on making a pilgrimage to the Vatican in Rome, he discovers a corrupt and bloated Church and a degenerate and cynical priesthood. The experience leads him to the writing of the 95 Theses, a call to arms against religious corruption and a return to the gospels of Jesus Christ. Central to the theses is Luther’s attack on the Catholic Church’s selling of Indulgence which are meant to ensure a dying person’s passage to Heaven. In calling for a spiritual renewal of Christianity, Luther’s 95 Theses lay the foundations for Protestantism. In episode two, “The Reluctant Revolutionary”, the Catholic Church responds to Luther’s attacks by charging him with heresy. But a fortunate historic confluence - the invention of the printing press - allows for the first time the wide dissemination of Luther’s ideas and beliefs which find popular support all across Europe. Luther attacks the Church hierarchy at his trial and his protests leads to revolutionary upheaval across the continent. The episode examines both Luther’s radical impact but also his refusal to support the peasant revolutionaries inspired by his rhetoric. Luther can imagine a spiritual revolutionary order but not an economic revolution. His vehement and ruthless attacks against the poor, the peasantry and against the Jews will resonate in Protestantism through the ages and lead to a tension in the Christian faiths which will see Catholicism brave the Reformation and paradoxically regain strength in the modern world as the Christian Church for the poor and the oppressed. Whatever the contradictions of his faith and life, the religious revolution inspired by Luther is undoubtedly one of the greatest singular moments in European history.

results.title: The Roman empire in the first century
results.creator_credit: Lyn Goldfarb, Margaret Koval, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Narrated by Sigourney Weaver, these four episodes focus on the rise of the Roman Empire. In episode one, “Order from Chaos” the Roman Republic has collapsed into the century-long chaos of civil war. Julius Caesar’s victories have led to the expansion of the Empire. But with Caesar’s murder in the senate, Augustus is made Emperor and the beginning of a hereditary dictatorship is put in place. Augustus’ rule results in the further expansion of the Empire and the rise of Roman art and architecture but his sometimes ruthless squashing of enemies foretell the problems that will lie ahead for the empire. In episode two, “Years of Trial”, we begin with the death of Augustus in 14 AD. Tiberius becomes emperor and though initially popular, he soon shows signs of tyranny. The fortunes of Roman citizenship are viewed through the eyes of the poet Ovid. The life of Roman citizens becomes even more horrific with the ascendancy of Caligula as Emperor, whose madness manifests itself in the belief that he is a God and whose excesses become increasingly sadistic and dangerous for Rome. In the Eastern province of Judaea a religious prophet named Jesus brings Roman occupation and Jewish resistance to loggerheads. In episode three, “Winds of Change”, the terror of Caligula’s reign is replaced by the provident and wise rule of Claudius. But the decadence of hereditary rule results in his murder by his unscrupulous wife who places her son Nero on the throne. The new Emperor is tutored by the Stoic philosopher, Senenca. By witnessing the accommodations to power that Seneca makes - at odds with his egalitarian philosophy - we witness the tensions of Roman citizenship, with a past built on Republican grandeur and a present built on hereditary empire. At the outposts of the empire, the English warrior queen Boudicca (Bodicea) wars against the Romans who massacred her family and kin, and in Judaea the Jewish zealot Saul is converted to Christianity, and as Saint Paul begins a missionary life that will see Christianity spread through the Roman Empire. In the final episode, “Years of Eruption”, the city of Rome is besieged by fire and Nero is put to death for his calamitous excesses. A new period of civil wars begins and Vestpatian is finally made Emperor. The kingdom of Judaea is crushed and the Temple in Jerusalem is destroyed. The city of Pompeii is buried by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius but with its excavation in the 1600s we have a permanent record of Roman art and life: that of the nobles and that of the slaves, that of the women and of the men. The episode ends with the ascendancy of Trajan to the throne of Emperor.
results.title_for_label: The Roman empire in the first century
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lyn Goldfarb, Margaret Koval, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)

results.title: The Greeks: crucible of civilization
results.creator_credit: Cassian Harrison, Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.) and Atlantic Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Narrated by Liam Neeson, these three episodes examine the rise and eventual collapse of the ancient Greek empire in the fifth and fourth centuries BC. In episode one, “The Revolution”, we look at the rise of classical Athens through the eyes of Cleisthenes, a nobleman who assisted in the development of democracy. Initially a small city-state, Athens was riddled by aristocratic antagonisms and fear of the warrior city-state of Sparta. By developing a political system of “equals” rather than an economy of tyranny, Cleisthenes and his fellow citizens developed the world’s first democracy. In episode two, “The Golden Age”, the rise of democratic Athens was threatened by the might of the Persian Empire. Under the generalship of Themistocles, the Athenian navy conquered the Persians and the resulting victory gave rise to a Greek empire that intellectually and economically dominated the Mediterranean world. Over this period, Greek culture developed the roots to modern philosophy, science, rationalism, art, drama and culture. Under the leadership of Pericles, the Parthenon was built and the city of Athens grew into the world’s most important state. In episode three, “Empire of the Mind”, the death of Pericles leads to civil violence and dissent and the fracturing of democracy into mob rule. Critics of the state, such as Socrates, are punished and executed but with the fall of Greece as a great military power there arises instead a cultural legacy of reason and philosophy which sees the Socratic method becoming the founding basis of Western civilisation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cassian Harrison, Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.) and Atlantic Productions
